Starting with summer jobs at IBM's market research department, continuing as a math instructor at U C Berkeley and elsewhere, I have run into statistics and their uses for several decades.

One of the most interesting things you see in this field is that effects multiply. That is, if two factors contribute to some result, and both of them improve a little, the result improves a lot. You could think about the contribution of brains and beauty to success if you want an example.

What this means in regard to poverty and social mobility is that a little improvement across the board should result in big improvements for everyone. We do not have to totally renovate the city transportation systems -- we do have to improve them by five or ten percent, while we simultaneously increase the minimum wage by five or ten percent, improve vocational education somewhat, etc. Miracles are not needed, just common sense and hard work.

One example of this effect (called the 'lognormal' distribution) is personal income. Any bright high school or college math student should be able to explain it to any state legislature or city council.

I lived in Atlanta during the construction of Marta. The first mistake was choosing a heavy rail underground instead of above ground light rail system.
Then as you stated, the white flight suburb counties like Cobb and Gwinnett (where the jobs were) did everything in their power to block Marta at the border. Only the North line offered inner city blacks and whites access to areas of employment.
The irony, the white flight group didn't factor in that some poor blacks and whites could drive. Now the fear/flight/ sprawl has spread for hundreds of miles creating one of the longest mind numbing commutes on the planet. Plus an albatross transportation system that requires a car to get to, and usually a car at the other end.
I now live in France, in 30 minutes (1/3 the time it took to get to Atlanta ) I can connect to a rail system that reaches every major European center.

"And in Atlanta poor and rich neighborhoods are far apart because, basically, everything is far apart; Atlanta is the Sultan of Sprawl, even more spread out than other major Sun Belt cities."

Actually, in Atlanta, poor and rich neighborhoods are far apart by design. The patterns of migration are obvious to anyone who has lived there for some time. As middle class African-Americans moved from the city proper into the nearby surrounding suburbs, White residents of those areas moved further out. The degree of sprawl is not some mere accident of geography.

"This would make an effective public transportation system nearly impossible to operate even if politicians were willing to pay for it, which they aren’t. As a result, disadvantaged workers often find themselves stranded; there may be jobs available somewhere, but they literally can’t get there."

It is also not strictly correct to state that it is impossible to operate an effective public transportation system. The reality is that attempts to expand Atlanta's efficient MARTA rail system into the more affluent far northern suburban counties met with stiff resistance from residents of those areas. I'll let you draw your own conclusions as to why that was.

The end result of all this is that, as you state, the poorest inner city residents have a difficult time reaching jobs further out of the city, limiting their prospects. It also leaves exurban residents with some of the longest commuting times in the nation.

Our urban sprawl may be a sign of growth,

Not only no social services, but no family or community structure. We move away from those supports in order to drive the economy. When the economy fails, it's not easy to put those networks back together.

So, it's going from here to there, just cross town -- fast, safe, inexpensive, even in a sprawling city.

Can we not do that? With local jobs. Do we call China for help again?
"Atlanta is the Sultan of [urban] Sprawl": if so,  cross-town mobility may be the real problem.  Right?

The Twin Cities are trying to reverse the sprawl trend. With the Green line linking downtown St. Paul with downtown Minneapolis( via the central corridor...going right through the University of Minnesota) slated to start running in 2014, I'm seeing more and more of my suburban friends moving into downtown.

Here, downtown is definitely becoming more attractive for those that can afford it. If there's one complaint, it's the lack of close in grocery stores. And the stores that are going in are the upscale Lund's and Byerly's, not the Cubs and Rainbow that the more cost conscious shop. And while the poorer neighborhoods are still to be found in the first residential ring, these areas are already sited for "redevelopment."

Redevelopment is a code word for gentrification. Neighborhoods trending gentrification (like Nord'East is doing now) will ultimately price out the current residents. Whether or not this is a good thing is determined by your own perspective and expectation. And there is a great deal of local disagreement.

The economic divide will continue to play a major role in the redevelopment of cities, but not necessarily to the benefit of those who have held on the longest.

My grandparent lived about 35 miles out of Atlanta and I recall a time before I-20, when the drive in was at least one hour. Now the entire area has become another replicate of any number of other megalopolises. I recall at the time that they were genuinely annoyed by the northerners who were buying up properties and turning the relatively quiet area into more New Jersey. But this attitude ignored the complicity of the local residents, many of who were and are easily as dogged in the pursuit of growth at any cost as any eastern real estate developer. It wasn't so long ago that all those condos and shopping plazas were open land with trees and wildlife.

I lived in Atlanta during the first phase of its rapid growth. I saw bad decision after bad decision made to serve the wants of the developers and business community. There are a lot of forward-thinking, good people in Atlanta, but their voices were mostly drowned out in the name of rampant development. Choking traffic, endless sprawl, and soulless neighborhoods were some of the results. There have been some efforts to change course, but so much damage has been done.

Head-in-the-sand politics there doesn't help either.

The thing that struck me is how badly this country needs to support women's health care, including contraception. This is one of the keys to breaking the cycle of poverty - the other being jobs. It's also apparent how little consequences are placed on young men, for the responsibilities and consequences of fathering children. Even this story states that one "became" pregnant - as a passive decision. I feel for these girls.

How shortsighted is that ? We need people who CAN read, not more that can't.
Free education AND contraception.

They are taught about birth control. They know how to use it. As one of my students put it, "Well, it was raining all weekend so's we had nothin' better to do & we were too lazy to get a condom, so's I got pregnant!" She told this to the entire class.

What I don't think people understand is how limited & hopeless their lives are. There is *nothing* in their future. Their parents are in jail, on drugs, unemployed, underemployed or else -on the other extreme - working three dead-end jobs. A baby for them is hope & a way to show they are adults. In my experience, the parents have the same worldview as their children. And *no one* even thinks about adoption. (Even in this article, the option is simply not raised.) Frankly, a lot of them are influenced by 'reality' shows that make celebrities of teen mothers. Hey, even Sarah Palin's daughter got pregnant & the dad was out of the picture & mom helped raised baby.The kids don't see that celebs are wealthy.When was the last time you saw a teen show promoting abortion or adoption?

I'm mostly a 'liberal,' but frankly part of the problem is that there are no short term economic downside to keeping the baby.They get welfare money. Conservatives say removing welfare is the solution, but what that fails to address is the endemic hopelessness & our corrupting societal values.Our first priority needs to be JOBS. Also the 'war on drugs' has been toxic for the poor. Finally, funding accessible public transportation would be huge.

My father was from a poor county in southwestern Virginia (it's actually called "Poor Valley," if you can believe it). My mother was from the Boston area. They met when he was in the Navy after World War II. He took her to his home, where poverty was rampant and there were no jobs. He drank with all his "boys," and they made their own moonshine to boot. After a short time, she told him that she was going back to Boston with her baby (me) in tow (they were, at least, married at the time). She gave him the chance: Come back with me and look for a job. He did. That's the only way he ever got out. Many of his friends stayed in Poor Valley and never got past that tree line.

When I was a child, we used to drive every summer to visit my father's "people." I remember being a teenager who was living in the not-so-wealthy suburbs of Boston and yet being stunned by the levels of poverty in Appalachia. I also recall seeing a "whites only" water fountain for the first time in the 1950s. Even then, I thought, "Why do they have so many babies?"

Indeed--why DO they have so many babies? Why aren't they taught about birth control? The abstinence nonsense simply doesn't work. How many lives have the potential of being saved if there were fewer of them? I believe in a hand up, not a hand out, and education about birth control--and availability of reliable methods--would do a world of good for these girls. It's a start, anyway.

LR, I am not a Repub, but a socially progressive Dem. Yet it is much more complicated than teaching teens about birth control.  Girls often get pregnant because it gives them an identity, something to do, makes them special, gives them someone to love who will love them back.  This is a much tougher problem to solve than handing out condoms and blaming Rs. these girls would not be doing drugs, getting pregnant, and hoping to somehow survive on a job at McDonalds if they had hope, better opportunities, and for the lack of those, yes I think we can blame the Rs a good deal, as well as the girls' families.  But I don't see any national leaders, R or D, helping them see beyond the tree line.  More's the pity, I think Randy Hatch is right when he says at 18, these kids have two ways to succeed:  either college (or maybe vo-tech) or join the military.  Motherhood is a great excuse not to join the military.  These girls do not have the grades, the skills or the money to get to college, let alone succeed there.  So they are doing "what comes naturally" either consciously or unconsciously: they are using their bodies, their human capital, to add some meaning to their lives.  I'm not saying I approve, but it's so clear that these girls have desperately few options. And what about the boys? Bless the young woman trying to help Destiny, but the odds are very long.

The desperate hopelessness of their lives leaves me gasping for air feeling caged.I was abandoned at 18 by Dad. Mom left when I was 15 leaving me acting Mom to younger sibs and home maker. Dad kicked me out when I was 18: his new wife jealous.My upper middle-class bubble burst. Friends away at college while I had a $1.35/hr coffee shop waitress job, living in 2 bdrm apt with 2 gals I'd just met. My addiction- not drugs or ETOH prevented me from making it past the first semester at college along with poor study skills.

My advantage over these girls:1) accomplished academically -HS diploma at 17, 3.8 GPA - to calculus, 5 yrs French, 2) my addiction not yet coined, but as debilitating as Heroin. In 1972 "bulimia" (severe: eat a 12 times a day and throw it up)- by 20 my hair and nails falling out from malnutrition, 3) bulimia disrupted my cycle so I didn't get preggers in teens and 20's.

I was 39 for 2 weeks when only child born - he's a frosh today at a top 10 US university. After a stint in every SF Bay looney bin for 2 yrs refusing their drugs from just before 21st Bday to 22, I moved back to CA to Mom's and her new husband. They took a Silicon Valley Disc company to IPO soon after I finished nursing school in 1985.4.0 , 2 college degrees.They gave me a loving base (did not pay rent or food), but I worked and bought factory new car.

Pro-lifer do-gooders help a few months for diapers, but forget the other 17 yrs.

Carroll's graduates need more school,parental type support.

Argh. Miranda... Bipolar. Eighteen. No relationship with the baby's dad. Why can't we do a better job of preventing people from having babies in circumstances like these?

It should be federal law to teach kids about birth control. And we should make birth control available for free at every drugstore.

But the right would not stand for this, because it would be both socialist and against God's plan. God wants teenage, unemployed and perhaps unemployable Miranda--who, loving as she clearly is, seems to have a number of problems and had to take her driver's test twelve times--to be a mom. He wants that so much, he hasn't even stopped to ask himself what it might be like to be raised by Miranda.

God is not worried about whether Miranda's home will be a stable place to grow up, or a chaotic one, although since he created bipolar disorder and is thus familiar with its effects, he knows it's likely to be the latter. Nor is poverty generally conducive to a serene home life.

I wish I could've reached into Miranda and Summer's brains and shown them that there were other paths--that's what Mr. Hatch tries to do, but I get that it is so hard if you've grown up with a particular "normal" to imagine that other "normals" are possible.

I also wish I could reach into Republican brains and say: Kids. Have. Sex. Grownups who get paid to govern create realistic policies geared to preventing teen pregnancy and stopping the cycle of poverty. If they're grownups with consciences, that is.

Those in power will never subscribe to the shift for as recognized, both political parties lack empathy for anyone but themselves. Ad long as they have six-figured salaries, roll-royce health care and pensions, we will continue the move towards the "Hunger Games" society.

At least here in NYC when we see population shifts due to rising real estate costs based on easy access to public transit, the MTA looks to expand service through Bus Rapid Transit ( based on it's budget, of course). This service isn't ideal, but it is based on ridership regardless of the income status of any particular neighborhood. It's both a good business model and serves to provide transit to those who need public transportation the most.

In NYC, Chicago, San Francisco, Boston, traffic congestion and the cost of parking make public transportation the best choice of getting to work for most people. Unless you've lived in those cities, or been to major European cities, getting out of the car, regardless of the commute time, is not within the realm of comprehension. Ask anyone in Atlanta what MARTA is called by those living there.

People always cite mass transit as the transport of the poor but real estate developers know otherwise. They know that they can place high end development anyplace there is good transit. Hence the rout of the L train in Brooklyn and Harlem are being developed and the economically disadvantaged will be driven away from the major public transport routes. That is why so many lower income workers come into the center city by car, usually in car pools and in wheezing jalopies. Ask your elevator man, the fellow or woman who sweeps up at night etc how they come to work and you will be amazed at how many come from great distances in venerable creaking ancient machines. Of course many commentators and even planners never check and never note this commonplace phenomenon.
The Arctic sea ice is in a death spiral due to additional hot air imported into the Arctic.
If the parents have to work long hours to provide for their children, there is little time for them to provide the nurturing care and supervision which is necessary to raising healthy children.

Krugman usually gets it right, but never so right as he gets it here. Atlanta (and I'm a native and live most of my life there) is not just a city built on dreams, it was a city built on a false imagination.  This is a city that still believes it can pave its way out of its problems, even though those problems were created by its pavement. It's a metro area that thinks it can sue its way out of its water problems even though those very problems are largely the result of its sprawl.  This is not a region even remotely equipped to resolve its own problems.

I don't know where to find the figures, but I'm pretty sure that central Los Angeles has long been the densest residential area on the U.S. Pacific coast. That's including San Francisco.

Unfortunately, the city for many years built freeways rather than public transit.

Have you noticed that in LA we're building subways? Sure LA has sprawl, but more and more LA is becoming a large city of neighborhoods and sooner, rather than later, we will have an enlarged subway system that links these neighborhoods, like the new EXPO line that is slated, in a couple of years to reach from Downtown to the beach in Santa Monica.

While viewing the US maps showing states and cities and how they rank respecting opportunity, I noted that Los Angeles, a city that is known for its urban sprawl, reflected a 9+ percent opportunity of making it to the top fifth. If a city is diverse and spread out as Los Angeles can offer more than twice the opportunity as Atlanta, it seems that there's more than urban sprawl that's at work.
